H0.text: Amphibians are the broad group of animals that are the first true tetrapods, vertebrates with four limbs.

H1.text: Fish are the broad group of animals that are the first true tetrapods, vertebrates with four limbs.

H2.text: Reptiles are the first true tetrapods, vertebrates with four limbs.

H3.text: Mammals are the first true tetrapods, vertebrates with four limbs.

A4.text: The earliest tetrapods, such as Ichthyostega and Acanthostega, are part of the stem group and not the crown group, which includes modern amphibians.

A5.text: Tetrapods evolved from lobe-finned fish, but the first true tetrapods (stem group) are distinct from fish themselves.

A6.text: The first major groups of amphibians developed in the Devonian period, from lobe-finned fish.

A7.text: The first tetrapod land vertebrates, basal amphibian organisms, possessed legs derived from these fins.

A8.text: The only known extant non-tetrapod sarcopterygians are the two species of coelacanths and six species of lungfishes.
